content: perhaps désister marks nothing negative, perhaps dé- does not determine -ister (-ester, ist, est: exist, subsist, consist), but dislodges it radically (this aradical root -ister) [cf. LI p. 159n]
linkedContent: perhaps désister marks nothing negative, perhaps dé- does not determine -ister (-ester, ist, est: exist, subsist, consist), but dislodges it radically (this aradical root -ister) [cf. LI p. 159n]

content: désistance (2 typical experiences) is ineluctable: 1) il faut que cela arrive: in this case, the “I,” the free subject, anticipates/precedes, is constituted w/out or before, the ineluctable event that happens to me 2) constitutive desistance of subject: something began before me, I am late, a subject marked in advance by a pre-impression, imprint—deconstitution (“I” am not the supporting basis of this imprint): still, ineluctable not genetic programs or historical determination—those would be supplemental, late determinations of ineluctable

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger never avoided anything? > how does one dare write such a sentence?
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger never avoided anything? > how does one dare write such a sentence?

linkedContent: how could a thinker of finitude, Heidegger, never avoid anything (ne jamais rien éviter)?

content: how can Lacoue-Labarthe trace the “hole” into which Heidegger “could not avoid falling”? is it a method, do we have to name it? neither a matter of seeing or knowing > Lacoue-Labarthe names a strategy: “turning movement,” “taken from behind,” “cut off from its support”

linkedContent: Ge-stell (bestellen, vorstellen, herstellen, nachstellen)

content: w/ both Lacoue-Labarthe & Heidegger, Derrida wonders about unity of unthought—couldn’t the unthought be désistance, & doesn’t désistance enforce an irreducible dispersion that disidentifies even a concept of a subject that exceeds the metaphysical one?

content: for Lacoue-Labarthe, mimesis is an essence w/out essence, is not, does not exist—desists (not negative)
linkedContent: for Lacoue-Labarthe, mimesis is an essence w/out essence, is not, does not exist—desists (not negative)

content: if one no longer denounces mimesis as fallen, [contra Plato], can’t call it originary: being originary incompatible w/ mimesis
linkedContent: if one no longer denounces mimesis as fallen, [contra Plato], can’t call it originary: being originary incompatible w/ mimesis

content: how is it possible to resemble mimesis w/out already being contaminated by it?
linkedContent: how is it possible to resemble mimesis w/out already being contaminated by it?

content: Heidegger installs himself upside down in Plato’s mimetology [?], attempts to rehabilitate a mimesis defined as a “disintallation,” as a “fall” that has happened to truth > Heidegger reads alētheia in Republic as Unverstelltheit (installation, non-disinstallation, stele)

content: fold or abyssal redoubling: désistance is first of all the désistance of truth: truth never resembles itself, so it resembles mimesis
linkedContent: fold or abyssal redoubling: désistance is first of all the désistance of truth: truth never resembles itself, so it resembles mimesis

content: truth never resembles itself, withdraws, masks itself, se désister (never ceases) ——ester: “to appear, present oneself in court” [p. 319n Kahn’s translation of Heidegger] > désistance, a rupture, heterogeneity w/ respect to Wesen, estance, not Abwesen (absence), Unwesen (disorder), Entwesen (inessentiality): dé, not negative, marks nonbelonging to family of ester

content: désistance brings to light anoia, not to be confused w/ madness though it can resemble it > double bind btwn 2 madnesses: 1) one of disintalling 2) one of reason, defensive stiffening (crispation) in assistance [Kafka], imitation, identification > madness against madness
linkedContent: désistance brings to light anoia, not to be confused w/ madness though it can resemble it > double bind btwn 2 madnesses: 1) one of disintalling 2) one of reason, defensive stiffening (crispation) in assistance [Kafka], imitation, identification > madness against madness

content: Heidegger & Levinas so close, so heterogenous: passage for a thinking translation
linkedContent: Heidegger & Levinas so close, so heterogenous: passage for a thinking translation

content: [in reference to method found in Lacoue-Labarthe] supplementary loop (boucle), tempted to call it a ring (anneau), voire bague (band), a certain circulation takes on value of prescription: obligation, injunction, alliance > detour & return path > inside and outside path of epochality
linkedContent: [in reference to method found in Lacoue-Labarthe] supplementary loop (boucle), tempted to call it a ring (anneau), voire bague (band), a certain circulation takes on value of prescription: obligation, injunction, alliance > detour & return path > inside and outside path of epochality

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger draws stehen and stellen together by identifying stal of stellein (to equip, to send word for) w/ sta of stele (column), he also links thesis via dhe to Setzung, Stellung, Lage—more philological Witz than true etymologism
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger draws stehen and stellen together by identifying stal of stellein (to equip, to send word for) w/ sta of stele (column), he also links thesis via dhe to Setzung, Stellung, Lage—more philological Witz than true etymologism

content: désistance: mimesis or its double, cela même qu’elle double et abîme (what it doubles & engulfs)— alētheia
linkedContent: désistance: mimesis or its double, cela même qu’elle double et abîme (what it doubles & engulfs)— alētheia

content: mimesis as désistance (w/out being it) is missed when one decides to identify it, one misses what it lacks and that this lack is not proper; Lacoue-Labarthe: mimesis ek-sists, better yet “de-sists,” infinity of substitution & circulation (must think of Nietzsche again)
linkedContent: mimesis as désistance (w/out being it) is missed when one decides to identify it, one misses what it lacks and that this lack is not proper; Lacoue-Labarthe: mimesis ek-sists, better yet “de-sists,” infinity of substitution & circulation (must think of Nietzsche again)

content: for Heidegger, opposition btwn inadequate/adequate circumscribed by alētheia’s withdrawal—yet, Lacoue-Labarthe’s mimesis haunts alētheia w/ unstable homoiōsis ——abyss of pre-originary mimesis, “precedes” truth, introduces desire for homoiōsis > Derrida explains how, w/ this thinking, Lacoue-Labarthe dislocates Heidegger’s epochal history

content: haunted by mimesis: loop or supplementary torsion, the ring both one more and one less in epochal chain, dissimulates itself [disorganizes/interrupts Heideggerian deconstruction?]
linkedContent: haunted by mimesis: loop or supplementary torsion, the ring both one more and one less in epochal chain, dissimulates itself [disorganizes/interrupts Heideggerian deconstruction?]

content: Lacoue-Labarthe (w/ rigor & prudence) follows folds of what can no longer be called scene, period, history, sequence—a deportation whose measurelessness (démesure) seems to defy hope of judgment/justice > and yet, there’s an il faut, there’s philosophy & its law
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe (w/ rigor & prudence) follows folds of what can no longer be called scene, period, history, sequence—a deportation whose measurelessness (démesure) seems to defy hope of judgment/justice > and yet, there’s an il faut, there’s philosophy & its law

content: désistance: one of the most demanding thoughts of responsibility > that the traditional categories don’t suffice places irresponsibility rather on the side of these categories: how can one assume responsibility in désistance, the responsibility of désistance itself?
linkedContent: désistance: one of the most demanding thoughts of responsibility > that the traditional categories don’t suffice places irresponsibility rather on the side of these categories: how can one assume responsibility in désistance, the responsibility of désistance itself?

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: traversed from the beginning by discourse of others, “subject” does not incur a simple Spaltung (splitting) > the latter, w/ its oppositional logic (absence/position), creates obsession w/ appropriation dominating analysis of mimesis, & also its economic, political bearing
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: traversed from the beginning by discourse of others, “subject” does not incur a simple Spaltung (splitting) > the latter, w/ its oppositional logic (absence/position), creates obsession w/ appropriation dominating analysis of mimesis, & also its economic, political bearing

content: Platonism denounces in mimesis (in désistance) madness, feminization, hysteria
linkedContent: Platonism denounces in mimesis (in désistance) madness, feminization, hysteria

content: no matter how “free” or deconstructed the response, one cannot reduce the delay (retard): an event, a law, a call are already there (others are there, for/before whom one must answer); “response inaugurates nothing if it does not come after”

linkedContent: rhythm: to think désistance as it is written

linkedContent: Hölderlin: all is rhythm (Rhythmus), destiny of man a single celestial rhythm

content: Mallarmé: every soul is a rhythmic knot
linkedContent: Mallarmé: every soul is a rhythmic knot

content: though Heidegger recalled that Georgiades translated rhuthmos as Gepräge (imprint, seal, type, character), this didn’t prevent him from bringing typos back to ontotypology & subject back to epoch of subjectity

content: Derrida says that no dialectic can overcome (ne saurait venir à bout) double constraint, double law, that of knot & caesura, obligation & cut (i.e. rhythm) > but then wonders if double bind is too dialectical, so he thinks of an arrythmic gap, hiatus, caesura, another undecidable ——un autre indécidable, the gap/hiatus in an undecidable derived from dialectical calculation/contraction, arrhythmic caesura as respiration of rhythm (this necessity awaits us) [pas, heartbeat]
linkedContent: Derrida says that no dialectic can overcome (ne saurait venir à bout) double constraint, double law, that of knot & caesura, obligation & cut (i.e. rhythm) > but then wonders if double bind is too dialectical, so he thinks of an arrythmic gap, hiatus, caesura, another undecidable ——un autre indécidable, the gap/hiatus in an undecidable derived from dialectical calculation/contraction, arrhythmic caesura as respiration of rhythm (this necessity awaits us) [pas, heartbeat]

content: “too late and too early”

content: Lacoue-Labarthe is at every instant as close & as far as could be from Theodor Reik > tells you everything you need to think law of this paradox (hyperbologic) [re: rhythm]
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe is at every instant as close & as far as could be from Theodor Reik > tells you everything you need to think law of this paradox (hyperbologic) [re: rhythm]

content: for Lacoue-Labarthe [?], anyone linked to edge of madness (au bord de la folie), the autobiographical (allobiographical) adventure, and its doubles, and the other, and death, is concerned w/ rhythm (the musical obsession) (Nietzsche, Hölderlin, Rousseau, Reik, Mallarmé)

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: caesura is empty moment, intrusion of prophetic word (Tiresias)
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: caesura is empty moment, intrusion of prophetic word (Tiresias)

content: caesura marks withdrawal of divine, plays at & undoes mourning > doubles work of mourning (the speculative, the dialectic, the opposition, the identification, the nostalgic interiorization, even the double bind of imitation), caesura takes one’s breath away (coupe le souffle), open mouth, pour donner, pour recevoir: quand elle a de la chance, gives one speech

content: interrupts alternation, constraint of opposition, even double bind [cf. p. 225]
linkedContent: interrupts alternation, constraint of opposition, even double bind [cf. p. 225]

content: no rhythm w/out caesura > antirhythmic [Hölderlin], arrhythmic
linkedContent: no rhythm w/out caesura > antirhythmic [Hölderlin], arrhythmic

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: subject in mirror is first of all subject in désistance, figure is never one, destabilizing division of figural (this muddles Lacan’s distinction btwn symbolic/imaginary)

content: Bataille: what forces me to write is the fear of going mad
linkedContent: Bataille: what forces me to write is the fear of going mad

content: obsessionality, re: writing, no longer clinical category
linkedContent: obsessionality, re: writing, no longer clinical category

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: désistance as a desertion [Derrida quotes a passage w/out usage of désistance] that is prior to any ‘self-possession’ (not mode of dispossession), (de)constitution of subject, can one think of loss re: what one never had?
linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: désistance as a desertion [Derrida quotes a passage w/out usage of désistance] that is prior to any ‘self-possession’ (not mode of dispossession), (de)constitution of subject, can one think of loss re: what one never had?

content: Lacoue-Labarthe: Gestalt and Darstellung can be derived from Ge-stell ——to lose track of Darstellung is to lose track of abyssal structure that can always divide & fictionalize it [it being Darstellung] [re: Lacoue-Labarthe on Heidegger’s use of Gestell]

content: subject—nothing other than formation of movement of désistance
linkedContent: subject—nothing other than formation of movement of désistance

content: Derrida wonders if Heidegger’s insistence on Ort, Erörterung, a unique site of gathering, leaves un-thought désistance or dislocation, which might be thought itself [this torments Derrida’s respect for Heidegger, along w/ Derrida’s insufficient concern re: authentic thought]

content: delay as inevitable, delay re: one’s “own” birth, experience of “abortion” > a subject that cannot identify itself because ineluctably delayed [Lacan’s human born prematurely]
linkedContent: delay as inevitable, delay re: one’s “own” birth, experience of “abortion” > a subject that cannot identify itself because ineluctably delayed [Lacan’s human born prematurely]

content: condition of possibility of identification is its impossibility (both ineluctable) > subject identifies itself because it can never be identified
linkedContent: condition of possibility of identification is its impossibility (both ineluctable) > subject identifies itself because it can never be identified

content: does Lacoue-Labarthe define a subject from which Heidegger protects himself (and seeks relief [assistance])?

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

content: Lacoue-Labarthe’s subject proves and undergoes (fait la preuve et l’épreuve) the contrary > identifies itself by way of désistance that makes absolute identification impossible

content: Derrida’s description of Lacoue-Labarthe’s description of Reik’s methodical failure: a floundering (enlisement), failure, abortion—slow sinking (enfoncement lent) structure of limit w/out opposition: not the single blow of failure, a repetition (sinking), a narrative

content: introduction is a garrulous index, when not an irremediable betrayal
linkedContent: introduction is a garrulous index, when not an irremediable betrayal

content: abortive: a birth takes place w/out taking place: event of a singular failure, “comes to itself only to lose itself” [re: Lacoue-Labarthe on Reik’s theory of autobiography]

content: [re: Reik] Derrida asks: can we link that which is not yet ontotypological or mimetological in pre-Platonic Greece w/ experience of non-musical Jewish shofar?

content: Lacoue-Labarthe’s hyperbologic programs inevitable “logic” of mimesis, converts gift of everything to gift of nothing, to gift of thing itself

content: resistance to désistance is desire for assistance, paternal assistance, Oedipal help ——unavoidable resistance to désistance as nonpathological inhibition, no rhythm w/out it, can say the same about the double bind (see p. 228 return to father, subject to law as inhibition, defense) [a safeguarding, a filiation, a subjectivity compelled by the caesura?]

content: play of de- might belong to hyperbologic, belongs to and escapes its own series: “gift of mimesis,” “gift of impropriety,” not negative (dialecticizable)

content: deconstruction (as/via [?] supplementary ring [anneau]) sometimes a task (tâche), sometimes an event (in a “practical” situation) > Lacoue-Labarthe says deconstruction’s a word “not in the least ‘worn out (usé)’” [cf. REST p. 277 ring linked to Van Gogh’s trap?]
